handDesc.p: Halantas. Final T in l1 seems to be a slightly reduced ta with a headmark much like the regular one; it may also be an erroneous ta instead of T.

Other palaeographic observations. The consonants ka and ra occur in both short and long forms. Anusvāra is usually above the character to which it belongs, but often to the right of that consonant and occasionally atop the next character (e.g. l8 maṁgi; l9 kuṭiṁbinas; l11 vedāṁga; l22, ṁjalir). Dependent i and ī are rarely distinguished and are read as expected where there is no clear indication of either. See also the commentary.

div.ab: śā ś s an ā a sya li

app.note: Compare the Nutulapaṟu grant and London Plates of Maṅgi Yuvarāja, both of which use the same wording, though for Jayasiṁha rather than Kīrtivarman.

According to RM's note, ra looks like ru. However, the ū sign is curved upwards. In fact, it looks like saṁ was first engraved, then corrected to ra. In addition to this character, there may be something added below the line at this point, just to the right of the descender of ra. The strokes are quite conspicuous in the estampage, but not visible at all in the photos. No insertion seems to be required either here or in the next line at this point. I cannot read the inserted text, if that is what it is. Its first character may be a small ṇa, and this may be followed by one to three further small characters of whose shape nothing can be discerned.
The engraved text may in fact be saṁghāṭopalabdha-.

jayaśilat
i
ā
-pra ś s ūtāya praroha-prasūty-āmoda-
app.note: The characters taya are at the lower edge of the binding hole, and are therefore reduced in size and slightly distorted in shape. I cannot fully reconstruct RM's reading and emendation. At the end of line 4, he apparently reads jayaśilati and emends the final vowel to ā. A footnote by his editor completes this emendation to jayāsi-latā. In line 5 it is also clear that RM emends śū to sū, but I fail to understand what he intends with the word praroha, shown in his edition in round parentheses. He probably means this to replace the preceding word he reads as praśūtāya, but if so, then I do not see why he first emends that to prasūtāya. No matter what RM intended, we have a close parallel in lines 10-11 of the Koṇeki grant of Viṣṇuvardhana II, which describe Jayasiṁha I as °āneka-samara-saṁghaṭṭa-labdha-vijaya-śīlatā-prasūta-yaśaḥ-prasūtāmoda-gandhādhivāsita-sakala-dig-maṇḍalasya (where -prasūtāmoda- is probably erroneous for -prasūty-āmoda-). The phrase jaya-śrī-latā in place of jaya-śīlatā is unexpected, but the subscript r is unmistakeable in the photo even in its worn state. It is possible that all of praśūtaya at the beginning of line 5 was intended to be cancelled, in which case we are left with a more elegant compound involving jaya-śrī-latā; but the text is interpretable with the above minor emendations even if all characters are retained.

I follow RM in dismissing the second bhuja as superfluous dittography. There is a slight possibility that the first bhuja is in fact a different word beginning with bhu, and thus the second is not redundant. It is also possible that the second bhuja is not simply a product of dittography, but an erroneously engraved word influenced by the first bhuja. The Koṇeki grant of Viṣṇuvardhana II has sakala-lokāśraya-bhuja-yugaḷa-bala-namitāśeṣa- (describing Jayasiṁha), and the composer's intent may have been -bhuja-yuga- here.

I endorse RM's reading, which he prints as clear. In fact, both characters are somewhat problematic, though there is little doubt as to the reading. The first character has an exaggerated headmark and its right limb seems to be attached too far down. The second is apparently gi with an anusvāra placed in the middle of the circular vowel mark.

The ARIE report says the granted village is in canūṟpalli viṣaya. I believe its author must have read the locative ending pallyāṁ like I do even though RM ignores (or his edition omits) what seems to be a rather definite anusvāra at the end. As for the second character, I see no indication of u, much less of ū, but accept the joint testimony of two scholars who have read something of the kind here. It is clear from the photo that the surface is very worn here. The upper part of the third character definitely looks like ḻ, but a damaged ṟ (as read in ARIE) is not out of the question; in addition, the character could be ḫpa.

app.lem: itth ā a m a ā jñāpayati

app.note: The lower part of ccha is lost to the edge of the binding hole. It may also have been c.

Although RM prints most of this text as clearly legible, neither the estampage nor the photo confirms his reading. Though the syntax of the sentence is garbled, I expect only one name here (see the note to the translation). I cannot definitively exclude RM's reading. To my eye, the first illegible character does not seem likely to be śa; the second could perhaps be ma or vā; and the third is altogether indiscernible. My tentatively read Ā (apparently ignored or read as a punctuation mark by RM) could, on its own, be dra or vra, and my tentative ḍi (RM's gi) may also be di, dhi or vi.

In line 11, the character read as vi could well be ni or bhi, and the one read as sa is wholly indiscernible in the estampage, though it does resemble sa in the photo. The final consonant could also be v instead of n, and does not appear to have an e marker. RM seems to take all of this string as a topnym in the locative, but he does not discuss it at all in his introduction. An editorial footnote interpets this as the camping place, presumably of Maṅgi Yuvarāja, and identifies it as the village Maṇḍūru near the modern village Mopaṟṟu. Given the convincing identification, I accept the reading, but retain a great degree of doubt. second character in line 12 is a complex and strange conjunct free from damage that looks most like ñcū. Compare the very differently shaped ṇḍa further on in this line, and the very similar ñca in line 15. It is preceded by a conspicuous dot that may be an anusvāra, but is probably only the headmark on the right limb of ma. The following character, also undamaged, lacks a cross-stroke, so it looks like ḻū rather than ṟū. Moreover, given its flat top, dhū is also possible. Compare dha in line 13 which, though slightly damaged, looks very similar. The top of the following r has been worn off at the edge of the binding hole; conceivably, it may also have been k. I see no indication of an e attached to it, but one may have been lost along with the top of the body.
The plate is worn here, but the reading is unambiguous.
The ARIE report reads the name as mṟōpaṟṟu. I see no anusvāra here. The subscript part of the first character could be either ḻ or ṟ.

Although the modern village Yellavarru is close on the southeast to modern Moparru, RM's reading cannot be right. I see no way to read the first character as I; it seems to be ve, but could perhaps also be me or vo. The second is very clearly a conjunct with l in the upper part. The lower component looks like ḻ, but could be ṟ or th, perhaps even g (compare lgo in the next line). It is definitely not the usual cursive simplification of subscript l.
These characters are quite effaced in the estampage, but all are reasonably clear in the photo.

If RM's reading at the end of 2r is interpretable, then it may be correct. Both the estampage and the photo are quite clear, and to me the characters seem to be as shown in my edition; the first may perhaps also be kṣo. The first character on 2v seems to belong to this phrase. The Sanskrit words from the second character onward are reasonably clear in the photo.

app.note: In this place, śe or ge was first inscribed, then the right-hand side of the consonant was incorporated into an m, but the left and top parts were left in place.
Since the text is meaningful as received, I prefer not to emend to the standard version of this stanza.

div.head: Plates
div.p: Greetings. From the ocean that is the lineage of the Caḷukyas—who were deliberately appointed to kingship by the Divine Lord Mahāsena, who are protected by the band of Mothers, who are of the Mānavya gotra, who are sons of Hāritī, who attained kingship by the grace of Kauśikī’s boon, who perform the Aśvamedha sacrifice, and whose fame has spread as far as the oceans—had arisen a moon who was Kīrtivarman, who earned his great reputation by his political acumen naya , discipline vinaya and valour. His son was His Majesty King mahārāja Viṣṇuvardhana, who perfumed the complete circle of the quarters with pleasant fragrance from the efflorescence, which is glory, sprouting from the liana that is the victory goddess attained in the clash of many a battle. His son, His Majesty the supremely pious Junior Vallabha King yuva-vallabha-mahārāja Maṅgi, whose pair of feet are tinted by the hues of the rays from the gems fitted to the surfaces of the crowns of all the enemy kings bowed down by fear of the power of his arms that were a shelter to the complete world sakala-lokāśraya illuminated by his valour unique in the three worlds, commands all householders kuṭumbin —including foremost the territorial overseers rāṣṭrakūṭa —in Canuḻpalli district viṣaya as follows.

Let it be known to you that on the occasion of the winter solstice we have given the village named Mḻopaṟṟu with exemption from all taxes, the donation being sanctified by a libation of water, to Maṇḍaśarman, who is thoroughly versed in the Vedas and Vedāṅgas and devoted to the six duties, and who is the grandson of Agniśarman, a hiraṇyakeśin of the Vatsa gotra residing in Vanapaṟṟu and the son of ĀḍiśarmanAccording to RM’s commentary, there are three donees: Agniśarman, his grandson Suśarman (read by RM where I show a lacuna) and Maṇḍaśarman (son of Veṁgiśarman, the name I tentatively read as Āḍiśarman). I am, however, quite certain in spite of the necessity of a minor emendation, that the donee is Maṇḍaśarman, son of Āḍiśarman and grandson of Agniśarman. By RM's reading, only Agniśarman would have a residence, gotra and school, but he would have no named ancestors; the next person (the ostensible Suśarman) would have only a named grandfather, while Maṇḍaśarman would only have a named father. It is much more logical to assume a single Brahmanical lineage of three generations, with residence, gotra and school recorded only for the grandfather, as commonly done in related grants.—to this Maṇḍaśarman who is devoted to his lord Maṅgi Yuvarāja in astivihasana Maṇḍūṟūra.I cannot interpret this phrase; see the apparatus to line 11.

Its boundaries are as follows. To the east, Velḻavaṟṟu. To the south, Pulgoṭlapabulūru. To the west, Agūnakṣayyaṁ. Could akṣayya mean a previously granted Brahmanical holding akṣaya-nīvī ? To the north,
kḻocce ḍoḍuva
. The donated land is situated in between these. Let no-one pose an obstacle to the enjoyment of rights over it. He who does so shall be conjoined with the five great sins. Vyāsa too has said:
Many kings have granted land, and many have preserved it as formerly granted. Whosoever at any time owns the land, the fruit reward accrued of granting it belongs to him at that time.
He who would seize land, whether given by himself or by another, shall be born as a worm in faeces for sixty thousand years.
A seizer of granted land cannot be purified even by donating ten million cows, nor by performing a hundred Aśvamedhas, nor by constructing a thousand tanks.

It is not actual poison that is properly called poison: it is the property of a Brahmin that is said to be poison. Poison kills just the one man, while seizing the property of a Brahmin destroys his progeny.

Hereby I offer my respectful obeisance añjali to all future kings on earth, born in my lineage and in different royal lineages, who with minds averted from sin observe this ruling dharma of mine in its integrity.

O king, those donations given by kings in the past to generate merit dharma , wealth artha and fame, are now comparable to discarded garlands or vomit. What decent man would ever partake again of them?

Over and over again, RāmadevaThe name in this stanza is normally Rāmabhadra. begs all these future kings: “Each in your own time, you shall respect this framework of legality that is universally applicable to kings!”

The executor ājñapti in this matter is the lord īśa Ghanarāśi.Or, given the ending of his name rāśi, perhaps īśa should be understood to mean that Ghanarāśi is Śiva, i.e. a fully initiated Śaiva. His Honour Bhānuśakti, beneficent to subjects
is the writer of this decreeThe text ends abruptly here. See the commentary.

The text ends abruptly with the last line on 3r. I agree with RM that only a very small amount of text seems to be missing here, most probably identifying the writer of the text. RM believes a date was also lost here, but I do not find this likely on the basis of parallel grants. It is not clear whether the last bit of text in line 26 is prose or a garbled continuation of the indravajrā hemistich identifying the executor; nor is it clear whether Ghanarāśi and Bhānuśakti are two separate persons or only one. The intended text may for instance have been something like tac-chāsanasyāsya ca lekha-karttā. The photographs published by the National Museum include a picture of 3v, and there seems to be no trace of writing there whatsoever. Perhaps the text was intended to be complete as it is. The last character, li, may have been intended as an abbreviation for likhita, and the symbol after it might be an abbreviation marker. Assuming that the second hemistich intended by the composer was shortened by the scribe to fit the text on the plate, it seems most likely that Ghanarāśi was the executor and Bhānuśakti was the writer.

The issuer of these plates was identified in the ARIE report as Jayasiṁha I on the grounds that the seal bears the legend sarvasiddhi and only Kīrtivarman and Viṣṇuvardhana (I) are mentioned as ancestors in the genealogy. RM, however, asserts that maṅgi-yuva-vallabha-mahārāja is clearly the donor. While I must point out that neither instance of the name maṁgi is quite clear, the reading is indeed quite secure. RM adds that, since Maṅgi Yuvarāja’s seals have the legend vijayasiddhi, the seal may not be the original seal of this grant. He further supposes that reference to the closer ancestry of Maṅgi Yuvarāja was apparently left out by oversight. His editor in EI (probably K. G. Krishnan) adds in a footnote that there may have been a mix up of two different plates at a distant time. Moreover, RM notes that the donor’s epithet is sakala-lokāśraya in line 6, but says only that this means the same as Maṅgi Yuvarāja’s regular epithet sarvalokāśraya. However, the two epithets are not necessarily interchangeable. The question of the issuer needs further study.

Some details to consider are the following.
1, The phraseology of the grant has much in common with known grants of Maṅgi Yuvarāja. However, it has just as much in common with grants of Jayasiṁha I and Viṣṇuvardhana II, most especially with the Koṇeki grant of Viṣṇuvardhana II. Particularly noteworthy is the fact that all grants of Maṅgi known to me begin with a more mature version of the stock text śrīmatāṁ sakala-.
2, The genealogy begins with Kīrtivarman, whereas grants of Maṅgi known to me begin either with Jayasiṁha I or with Kubja Viṣṇuvardhana. Genealogies beginning with Kīrtivarman are found in all grants of Jayasiṁha I that I know, one grant of Viṣṇuvardhana II (of the two I know), and the single known grant of Indra Bhaṭṭāraka.
3, The exhortatory verses are unusual. Stanza 3 does not occur in any Eastern Cālukya grant I know of. Variants of stanza 4 occur (sporadically) only from the time of Vijayāditya I onward, and the first closely related variant is in a grant of Kali Viṣṇuvardhana. Stanza 6 occurs in at least one grant of Pulakeśin II, but among Eastern Cālukya charters, its only occurrence that I know of is in one of Bhīma I.
4, I have not verified this, but the elaborate headmarks of this inscription (usually long horizontal lines with the ends curved up) seem late to me. It may be that a later scribe was attempting to imitate an earlier style of writing. A more detailed study of the palaeography is warranted.

The idea that plates belonging to different grants have been mixed up strikes me as preposterous, since the page breaks concerned would have had to be at the same spot in the text. The idea that Indra Bhaṭṭāraka and Viṣṇuvardhana II were omitted out of oversight is likewise preposterous; moreover, the text progresses smoothly through kīrttivarmmaṇaḥ sūnor … śrī-viṣṇuvarddhana-mahārājasya priya-tanayaḥ … śrī-maṁgi(?)-yuva-vallabha-mahārājaḥ. Any omitted people would have had to have been included in the draft before priya-tanayaḥ, and the syntax would have been quite awkward. Forgery (produced some generations after Maṅgi Yuvarāja and probably using a genuine seal) seems quite likely, but I would expect a forger to have copied a specimen grant with alteration only in the executive section, rather than cobbling the text together from grants of different rulers.

The possibility also remains that it is an idiosyncratic charter of the Maṅgi Yuvarāja we are familiar with. And there is, in addition, some chance that we are dealing here with an unknown Maṅgi Yuvarāja from an earlier time. This person could be either Jayasiṁha I before his formal accession to the throne, or Indra Bhaṭṭāraka. The former did use the epithets sakala-lokāśraya and (probably) trailokya-vikrama, and if the problematic locus in line 8 correctly reads śrīmachrī instead of śrīmaṁgi, then “the majestic yuvarāja, son of Viṣṇuvardhana” would clearly identify him. The latter, in turn, may well have spent part (perhaps a large part) of his life as yuvarāja under Jayasiṁha I. Although he is not known to have been called sakala-lokāśraya (indeed, he was, at least after his coronation, siṁha-vikrama and, probably, rāja-lokāśraya), yet if his personal name had been Maṅgi and if yuvarāja had stuck to him as a permanent epithet, then that would to some degree explain why his grandson bore the name Maṅgi Yuvarāja as a crowned king.
